title: German submarine U-862
text:
German submarine "U-862 was a <a href="Type%20IX%20U-boat">Type IXD2</a> <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a> of <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>'s "<a href="Kriegsmarine">Kriegsmarine</a>" during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. After Germany's surrender in May 1945, "U-862" put into <a href="Singapore">Singapore</a> and was taken over by the <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Navy">Imperial Japanese Navy</a> under the name I-502".
"U-862" was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> on 15 August 1942 by <a href="DeSchiMAG">DeSchiMAG</a> <a href="AG%20Weser">AG Weser</a> of <a href="Bremen">Bremen</a>. She was <a href="ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> on 7 October 1943 with "<a href="Kapit%C3%A4nleutnant">Kapitänleutnant</a>" <a href="Heinrich%20Timm">Heinrich Timm</a> in command. Timm commanded "U-862" for her entire career in "Kriegsmarine", receiving a promotion to "<a href="Korvettenkapit%C3%A4n">Korvettenkapitän</a>" on 1 July 1944. "U-862" conducted two patrols, sinking seven ships totalling 42,374 tons.
Design.
<a href="German%20Type%20IX%20submarine%23Type%20IXD">German Type IXD2 submarines</a> were considerably larger than the original <a href="German%20Type%20IX%20submarine">Type IX</a>s. "U-862" had a displacement of when at the surface and while submerged. The U-boat had a total length of , a <a href="pressure%20hull">pressure hull</a> length of , a <a href="beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> of , a height of , and a <a href="draught%20%28ship%29">draught</a> of . The submarine was powered by two <a href="MAN%20SE">MAN</a> M 9 V 40/46 <a href="supercharged">supercharged</a> four-stroke, nine-cylinder <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s plus two <a href="MWM%20GmbH">MWM</a> RS34.5S six-cylinder four-stroke diesel engines for cruising, producing a total of for use while surfaced, two <a href="Siemens-Schuckert">Siemens-Schuckert</a> 2 GU 345/34 <a href="Motor%E2%80%93generator">double-acting electric motors</a> producing a total of for use while submerged. She had two shafts and two <a href="propeller">propeller</a>s. The boat was capable of operating at depths of up to .
The submarine had a maximum surface speed of and a maximum submerged speed of . When submerged, the boat could operate for at ; when surfaced, she could travel at . "U-862" was fitted with six <a href="torpedo%20tube">torpedo tube</a>s (four fitted at the bow and two at the stern), 24 <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a>es, one <a href="10.5%20cm%20SK%20C/32%20naval%20gun">SK C/32 naval gun</a>, 150 rounds, and a <a href="3.7%20cm%20Flak%2018/36/37/43">Flak M42</a> with 2575 rounds as well as two <a href="2%20cm%20FlaK%2030">C/30</a> anti-aircraft guns with 8100 rounds. The boat had a <a href="Ship%27s%20company">complement</a> of fifty-five.
Service history.
First patrol.
"U-862" was one of the most travelled of all <a href="U-boat">U-boat</a>s. She sailed from Germany in May 1944 and eventually reached <a href="Penang">Penang</a>, in Japanese-controlled <a href="British%20Malaya">Malaya</a>, in September 1944. Penang was the base for the 33rd U-boat Flotilla, code-named "<a href="Monsun%20Gruppe">Monsun Gruppe</a>" ("Monsoon Group").
On the way there, she launched a <a href="G7es%20torpedo">T5/G7es "Zaunkönig I"</a> <a href="acoustic%20torpedo">acoustic homing torpedo</a> at a tanker. The Zaunkönig came around full circle to home in on "U-862". Only an emergency crash dive and staying silent saved the U-boat from her own torpedo. She also shot down an Allied <a href="Consolidated%20PBY%20Catalina">Consolidated PBY Catalina</a> aircraft H of <a href="No.%20265%20Squadron%20RAF">No. 265 Squadron RAF</a> on 20 August 1944 and then escaped an intense search for her. She sank several merchant ships in the <a href="Mozambique%20Channel">Mozambique Channel</a> between Africa and <a href="Madagascar">Madagascar</a>.
Second patrol.
"U-862" departed for her second war patrol from <a href="Jakarta">Batavia</a> in the Japanese-occupied <a href="Netherlands%20East%20Indies">Netherlands East Indies</a> in December 1944. She sailed down the west coast of Australia, across the <a href="Great%20Australian%20Bight">Great Australian Bight</a>, around the southern coast of <a href="Tasmania">Tasmania</a> and then north towards <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a> where she sank the U.S.-registered <a href="Liberty%20ship">Liberty ship</a> on 25 December 1944. She then travelled around New Zealand and entered the port of <a href="Napier%2C%20New%20Zealand">Napier</a> at night undetected. This has given birth to an urban legend in New Zealand, where it is said that the captain of "U-862" sent sailors ashore at night to steal fresh milk from a farm. This may arise from a joke made by Captain Timm to Air Vice Marshal Sir <a href="Rochford%20Hughes">Rochford Hughes</a> in the late 1950s. "U862"'s voyage to New Zealand was portrayed in a stage comedy "U Boat Down Under" which was written and directed by Peter Tait and performed at <a href="Downstage%20Theatre">Downstage Theatre</a>, Wellington from 27 July to 5 August 2006.
"U-862" then returned to the Indian Ocean. On 6 February 1945, about 1,520 km (820 nm) south-west of <a href="Fremantle">Fremantle</a>, "U-862" sank the U.S.-registered Liberty ship, , which was loaded with <a href="mule">mule</a>s bound for <a href="Burma">Burma</a>.
"U-862" was also a trial boat for the FuMo 65 "Hohentwiel" <a href="radar">radar</a> system. This was cranked out of a casing on the port side of the conning tower and rose on a mast. The aerial was hand trained onto targets whilst the U-boat was on the surface. The radar had a range up to and was very effective where there was little risk from air attack on the U-boat.
Transfer to Japan.
When Germany surrendered on 8 May 1945, she put into <a href="Singapore">Singapore</a> and was taken over by the <a href="Imperial%20Japanese%20Navy">Imperial Japanese Navy</a>. On 15 July 1945 she became the IJN submarine "I-502". The "I-502" surrendered at Singapore in August 1945 and was scuttled in the <a href="Strait%20of%20Malacca">Strait of Malacca</a> at on 13 February 1946.
The German crew of "U-862" suffered no casualties, and some returned to Germany several years after the war. Others who were interned at <a href="Kinmel%20Camp">Kinmel Camp</a>, <a href="Bodelwyddan">Bodelwyddan</a>, North Wales, remained in Wales and settled in the neighbouring communities of <a href="Rhyl">Rhyl</a>, <a href="Rhuddlan">Rhuddlan</a> and <a href="Prestatyn">Prestatyn</a>, due to the risks of returning to the <a href="Soviet%20occupation%20zone">Soviet occupied areas</a> of Germany after the war. Two of the crew are buried at the new cemetery at Rhuddlan, North Wales, on nearby plots.
